repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Amos E. Dolbear Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into five series: Letters, publications, and writings; Telephone prototypes, models, and inventions; The Telephone Appeals and patent related documents; Photographs; and Personal and family papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes letters, publications, writings, personal papers, a commemorative Ballou Hall plaque, photographs, notebooks, and apparatus connected with Dolbear's academic work and with experiments regarding the invention of the telephone.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Amos Emerson Dolbear (1837-1910) was born in Norwich, Connecticut on November 10, 1837. Following his father's death, he and his mother moved to Newport, Rhode Island, where he remained with his mother until her death in 1847. He then went to live on a relative's farm in New Hampshire and eventually was sent to Worcester, Massachusetts, to learn a trade. He was employed briefly at a pistol-making factory. At the age of eighteen, he headed west, finding employment as a school teacher in Missouri. Suffering from poor health, he soon returned to New England and continued to carry out physically strenuous jobs in Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

Desiring a better education in order to advance professionally, Dolbear enrolled in Ohio Wesleyan University. As a result of his outstanding performance, he soon became an assistant in both the Physics and Chemistry Departments. He graduated in 1866 following two years of study and became an assistant instructor in the Chemistry Department the University of Michigan. He received two degrees, an MA and a ME, from Michigan. Dolbear then assumed the position of assistant professor of Natural History at Kentucky University. After two years he moved on to become professor of Physics and Chemistry at Bethany College in 1868. In 1869, he married Alice Hood, with whom he had six children. Before leaving West Virginia, he served as the mayor of Bethany from 1871-1872.

In 1874, Dolbear arrived at Tufts College, accepting the chair of the Physics and Astronomy Department and continued to pursue his interest of the study of the convertibility of sound into electricity. He stayed at the college for the remainder of his academic career.

Dolbear contributed many notable inventions to the scientific world, including the static telephone, the electric gyroscope used to demonstrate the Earth's rotation, the opeidoscope, and a new system of incandescent lighting. In 1876, Dolbear patented a magneto electric telephone, in 1879 a static telephone, and three years later he managed to communicate over a distance of a quarter of a mile without wires in the Earth and obtained a patent on the wireless telegraph before Hertz or Guglielmo Marconi. His research on the static telephone was conducted in his laboratory on the top floor of Ballou Hall, and the first transmissions using the device were made from Ballou Hall to his house on Professors Row. In 1876, Dolbear patented a magneto electric telephone, in 1879 a static telephone, and three years later he managed to communicate over a distance of a quarter of a mile without wires in the Earth. It is interesting to note that the Tufts professor was ahead of Hertz and Marconi. He received a U.S. patent for a wireless telegraph in March of that year.

Dolbear was a member of the American Association of Arts and Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science and worked as an examiner at the World's Fair. He was recognized for his contributions to science at both the Paris Exposition in 1881 and the Crystal Palace Exposition in 1882. He published several books, articles, and pamphlets, including "The Art of Projecting" (1876), "The Speaking Telephone" (1877), "Sound and its Phenomena" (1885), "First Principles of Natural Philosophy" (1897), "Modes of Motion" (1897) and "Matter, Ether, Motion."

Dolbear was one of only three faculty members to offer unqualified support to the College's decision to admit women beginning in 1892. In 1905-6, he became the first faculty member to be granted permission for a full academic year's leave with pay prior to the establishment of a sabbatical leave program at Tufts in 1908. Dolbear died on February 23, 1910 following a long illness.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

did.unittitle: Lectures, publications, and writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to Amos E. Dolbear's lectures and publications on a wide range of scientific and social science topics. The bulk of the material within this series are drafts of articles written for publication. The drafts are contained within numerous notebooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as found.

scopecontent.p: This folder contains both handwritten and typed copies of this article.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The notebook in this folder also contains information on galvanometers, tangent galvanometer, reflecting galvanometer, astatic galvonometer, resistance coils, standard cells, conductors, keys, experimental work, galvanometer reduction factor, resistance, resistance of batteries, Wheatsone bridge, primary batteries and their reactions, secondary batteries, and the relation of electromotive force to chemical reaction.

did.unittitle: Notebook # 35 Induction coils for commercial work (Cosmopolitan, Jan. 1895); Electricity in disinfection (Cosmopolitan, 1896); Electrical action upon living things in water (Cosmopolitan, Feb. 1896); Preface to Growth of Physical Knowledge; Preface to nat. philosophy; Science and pedagogical science (given in Boston, April 30, 1898); Reasons for Sunday observance (Free Religions Association, May 5, 1898)
Notebook # 36 On lightning; Vacuum tubes and Electric lighting (written for Cosmopolitan, May 5, 1896); What chemistry can do for mankind; The modern alchemist; antiquity of the Earth
Notebook # 37 Mechanism and life; On lightning; Eureka!; Galilio [Galileo], a physician; Newton; Franklin; Faraday; Joule
Notebook # 38 The phenomena of electricity (given Feb. 20, 1888); On nature of electricity (April 1888); On the growth of sciences
On telephone systems - lecture delivered at Franklin Institute, December 11, 1885
Writings A-C

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a typewritten bibliography of Dolbear's published works, which may not be complete. It also includes scientific articles written by and in response to Dolbear, a handwritten address given by Dolbear at Tremont Temple on May 27, 1892, and an address to teachers in Cheshire County, N.H. Marlboro. There is an essay on atomic vibration and maximum temperature,along with an essay concerning Dolbear's inventions and experiments in electricity, telegraphy, and telephony - both of which are written in Dolbear's hand.

did.unittitle: Writings D-E

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains handwritten, typewritten, and printed essays by Dolbear on a number of topics, including the direction of an electric current; disappointing results of teaching science (1893); the educational method in the light of evolution; and many topical essays related to electricity, from electricity and civilization to electricity as a weed killer and electric photography.

did.unittitle: Writings E

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains handwritten, typed, and printed essays on a number of electricity-related topics, electro-magnetism, and ether. Also included are essays on evolution and education; Emerson's thoughts on science, according to Dolbear; and a number of handwritten prompting notes. The copyright certificate for Dolbear's "Elements of Physics" is also included.

did.unittitle: Writings F-L

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dolbear's varied interests are represented by the writings in this folder. Articles about Moses Farmer, principles of social reform, the food supply in the future, the future of electricity, incandescent and fluorescent light, and life from a physical standpoint are included. Essays are handwritten, typed, or in printed forms.

did.unittitle: Writings M-N

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains Dolbear's writings on the topics of magnetism, matter, machinery, medication by electric osmosis, education, electricity, apparatus for demonstration the motion of the earth, nerves and knowledge, galvanometers, geometry, sun spots, astronomy and the portelectric system (electrical transportation).

did.unittitle: Writings O

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains works on a number of Dolbear's interests, including the importance of a knowledge of science (1888), introduction of physics to grammar school maximum temperatures, matter as energy, opinions, organization of atoms and molecules, vibrations and pitch, contact theory of electricity, physical nomenclature, and the appeal of food.

did.unittitle: Writings O

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dolbear's writings included in this folder cover the following topics: odds against uneducated inventors, importance of knowing your ancestors, chemismor chemical affinity and chemical attraction, electricity, electromagnets, gravity, immortality from the physical standpoint, high school science teaching.

did.unittitle: Writings P-R

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dolbear's writings on a number of topics, including a plan for electrical model of electric phenomena, philosophy of education, phenomena of vortex ringe, pedagogical physics, paracelsus, pioneer of science, relation of physics to ethics, religious life in colleges.

did.unittitle: Writings S-Z

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included in this folder are a number of Dolbear's writings on a variety of subjects, including a scheme for railroad signaling, the science and pedagogy of science (given at School Masters Club, 1898), science in schools, science in the 19th century, science and theism, science problems of the twentieth century, scientific bequest of the 19th to the twentieth century, may 1900 (duplicates article from June 7, 1900 with "unity" header removed), street dangers and unsightliness (1891), slate writing-psychic/medium powers (transcript which reveals Dolbear's brother was killed at Gettysburg), solving the mystery of life in the laboratory, the spectral well of Virginia (1893), strong ad week points in high school education, Sunday observance, teachers in the Ozarks (1906), telegraphing without wires, theism and ethics, science in schools (1893), thirty years ago at Ohio Weslyan (1895), viewing electromagnetic waves, truancy, truth, utopia, vacuum tube electric lamps (1896), Wilhelm Eduard Weber (1892), what can be done with a sunbeam (1901), will man ever fly (1894), wireless telegraph and the ether (1903), and wireless telegraphy and how it works (1902).

scopecontent.p: This is a bound scrapbook pf newspaper and journal clippings assembled by Dolbear. Although a number of the clippings relate to the telephone, several other topics on which Dolbear wrote.

Telephone prototypes, models, and inventions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains telephone prototypes, models, and other Dolbear inventions

Identification of prototypes and models in this series has been made by comparing the donor gift agreement, exhibit placards, and, in some cases, tags attached to the artifact. No direct comparison has been made between the objects and plans, designs, or patent documents found elsewhere in the collection.

Missing from this series is a model wall phone for demonstration at World's Fair bearing label "Dolbear Electric Telephone Co. The unit had a static generator and ringing generator (the latter using horseshoe magnets) and includes two bells and a switch shutting off the circuit when receiver is hung up.
Also missing is an enclosed rotophone, a double coil permanent magnet receiver with diaphragm between two magnets, and two receivers or transmitters.

Also included is one telephone prototype and components retrieved from the attic of Robinson Hall (Physics Department) before the building's renovation in 2015. It is unclear whether the components were disassembled from a single prototype, or include spare parts from other projects. This accession is housed in three boxes: 034, 035, and 036.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as found.

did.unittitle: Early experimental form of magnetic telephone. Consists of two small horeshoe magnets mounted on board containing diaphragm and coil.

did.unittitle: In the High Court of Session, First Division, Edinburgh: the United Telephone Company (Limited) v. Alexander Maclean, Edinburgh. Specially reported for the Telegraphic Journal and Electrical Review
Photographs and plaque

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographic materials and one plaque. With a few exceptions, all are portrait photographs of Amos E. Dolbear. Other subjects include a photograph of Dolbear's house on Professors Row, a photograph of Eugene B. Bowen, '76 with Benjamin L. Dolbear, Dolbear's son, and the tablet honoring Dolbear given by Bowen, Richard E. Dolbear, Dolbear's grandson, holding an electric gyrostat, another picture of the gyrostat, and two unidentified photos.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as found.

did.unittitle: Amos E. Dolbear commemorative plaque (Ballou Hall)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavy metal plaque. Amos Emerson Dolber, Professor of Physics, 1874-1906. Inspiring teacher -- creative scientist. Within these walls Professor Dolbear invented in 1876 the first permanent magnet telephone and the electrostatic telephone in 1879 for the transmission of speech without wires. Presented by Eugene Bucklin Bowen of class of 1876, in memory of his teacher. 1949.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Amos E. Dolbear

did.unittitle: Photographs related to Amos E. Dolbear

scopecontent.p: This folder contains a photograph of Amos E. Dolbear's house at 134 Professors Row, samples of the equipment he invented, his grandson, Richard E. Dolbear holding an electric gyroscope, and Eugene B. Bowen, '75, pointing to the plaque honoring Professor Dolbear, which he gave to the College c. 1949. No Date available

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Dolbear's professional correspondence, condolence letters and family materials, and correspondence and materials written and collected by colleagues representing him at the London and Paris exhibitions of 1881.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as found.
